item.title: CRT Shader
item.author: Author
item.description: Shader CRT Shader, or something. Code Vertex Shader attribute vec2 position; varying vec2 vPosition; void main() { vPosition = position; gl_Position = vec4(position, 0.0, 1.0); } Fragment Shader precision highp float; varying vec2 vPosition; uniform float uTime; uniform sampler2D uSampler; void main() { vec2 ndc = vPosition; // Bend the texture coordinates across a sphere-ish thing // Add some scan-line noise vec2 tpos = vPosition * vec2(0.

item.title: Math Battle
item.author: Author
item.description: Description A game where you need to write math functions to guide your missile. A player wins when their math function intersects the other players circle. The asteriods were originally supposed to be destructable, but I did not finish it.

item.title: ErgoDox EZ Trackball Mod
item.author: Author
item.description: Introduction Recently I purchased an ErgoDox EZ ergonomic keyboard. I figured if I’m going to spend all my time at the computer, might as well save my wrists. I was also excited about the open source nature of the ErgoDox and the rave reviews.

item.title: Getting Started With Incr_dom - Part 3
item.author: Author
item.description: Note: Incr dom is superceded by a new, much easier to use library called Bonsai In this installment of the tutorial we’ll get the basics of the Tetris game working.

item.title: Getting Started With Incr_dom - Part 2
item.author: Author
item.description: Note: Incr dom is superceded by a new, much easier to use library called Bonsai This installment will add the basic frame of the single page application. We’ll create a menu and be able to navigate between the various pages.

item.title: Getting Started With Incr_dom - Part 1
item.author: Author
item.description: Note: Incr dom is superceded by a new, much easier to use library called Bonsai Incr_dom is a library created by Jane Street for building web applications using OCaml.

item.title: Maze Program
item.author: Author
item.description: Introduction This is part of an old program series I’ll be writing up. During college I was into Computer Graphics, Compilers, Operating Systems, anything that got to the “heart” of practical computing.

item.title: OCaml is Cool
item.author: Author
item.description: Note: This is a filler document Why is OCaml cool? It’s statically typed, compiles fast, immutable by default, expressive. Below is the basic OCaml hello world. let _ = print_endline "Hello World!
